overview.short: Helicobacter pylori is a Gram-negative, spiral, motile bacterium that colonizes the stomach and is strongly urease-positive.
overview.clinical_context: Classically associated with chronic gastritis, peptic ulcer disease, and increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma and MALT lymphoma.

species_markers.notes: Strong urease positivity is the classic defining lab feature for H. pylori.
Growth under reduced O2 with CO2 supports H. pylori.
Spiral morphology supports Helicobacter; not exclusive at genus-level.

common_confusions.reason: Curved/spiral Gram-negative morphology overlap; typically urease-negative.
Both are gastric Helicobacter species; differentiation often requires histology or molecular methods.

when_to_question_identification: Urease negativity argues strongly against H. pylori.
Strict aerobiosis or anaerobiosis is inconsistent with H. pylori.
Robust growth at 42Â°C strongly suggests Campylobacter rather than H. pylori.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Fast and highly supportive for H. pylori in gastric samples.

recommended_next_tests.test: Stool antigen test or urea breath test
recommended_next_tests.reason: Non-culture clinical confirmation methods commonly used for H. pylori.
